content: No information provided. Jackie Roosevelt Robinson, born on January 31, 1919, in Cairo, Georgia, was a standout athlete at the University of California Los Angeles. He made history in 1947 as the first black player in Major League Baseball with the Brooklyn Dodgers. Robinson's exceptional performance earned him the National League's Rookie of the Year Award in his first season and the Most Valuable Player award in 1949. He was later inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1962. Jackie Robinson's achievements extended beyond athletics, influencing civil and human rights in America. He was the first black player in Major League Baseball, gaining widespread admiration for his fortitude, integrity, and athletic ability. Robinson was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1962 and was highly popular in America, ranking ahead of prominent figures in a national poll. Jackie Robinson's influence extended beyond athletics as he was named vice president of Chock Full O' Nuts and co-founded the Freedom National Bank of Harlem. He worked with various organizations to improve the lives of Americans and his legacy is upheld by the Jackie Robinson Foundation, providing educational opportunities for children from low-income families. His personal achievements have had a lasting positive impact on civil rights in the United States. The President is authorized to present a gold medal to Jackie Robinson's family in recognition of his contributions. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal. Duplicates may be sold in bronze. The medals are considered national medals. Authorization of appropriations is granted. The medals struck under this Act are national medals for purposes of chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code. An amount not to exceed $30,000 is authorized to pay for the cost of the medal, with proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals deposited in the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund. Congress suggests designating a national day to recognize Jackie Robinson's accomplishments. The Senate passed S. 300 on October 17, 2003, to award a congressional gold medal to Jackie Robinson posthumously for his contributions to the nation. Congress also suggests establishing a national day in recognition of Jackie Robinson.
